content.description: This route is to the left of Resurrection and uphill slightly. P1 5.10 Yang: 100' approx. Starts in great jam crack then widens for the rest of the way. Gear & 5 bolts. At the top after roof you will go up left onto large ledge to find anchor. Step around corner to left of anchor to see P2: 5.9 Yin: 90' approx. You can leave the big gear at this anchor (largest needed is #4). At top of P2 anchor, you can scramble above to top out. Two raps with 70m, though a 60m *probably* will work. Rap off P2 anchors to top of P1, then rap P1 directly down from P1 anchors.
content.protection: P1: Small to .5 size cams, two #2, one #3, two #6's, and one Big Bro. P2: Standard-#4...    Draws & slings.
content.location: See pic-If you are looking at the chimney of resurrection, just look to the left of that route for the next wide looking crack. You cross the creek, just balance up a log and scramble up hill a little. The crack that gets wide is unmistakable.

content.description: Alternative sporto first pitch for resurrection. Thin, balancy crimps and side pulls of a fairly continuous nature.
content.location: Obvious sport line 25 right of the left side chimney on the Tombstone.

climbs.name: Resurrection
climbs.fa: Scott Duemler/Aaron Collins/Mark Geikenjoyner. FFA David Bloom

content.description: Just downstream of Bird of Prey is a large, tombstone shaped monolith split by chimneys on both sides. Resurrection goes up the left side chimney for pitch 1, 5.9 4 bolts and gear to ledge then moved right to anchor. P2 up good rock past bolts and sparse gear over slightly overhanging thin holds/side pulls past a juggy roof then easier climbing to anchors, 12a. Long and strenuous.
content.protection: 9 quickdraws, small rack of doubles from .3 to .75, one #1 and one #3.
content.location: On the tomstone, out of the darkness and into the light!

content.description: Step across water from rock, step up to place good, small cam then up and reach left to clip bolt. Pull past cruxy spot and continue up crack system past another bolt, more fingers and jugs on rock that is soft at times. Last 10 feet kind of dirty but protected by a bolt. Mantle onto big ledge then go right on ledge 10 feet to bolted anchor.
content.protection: 3 bolts, triples from .3 to .75 (get a bunch of overlapping cams in that range) doubles #1 and #2. There are good opportunities for placing nuts on the route and hexes would also be useful in a couple spots.
content.location: Left of Yang and Yin about 100 meters and right of Knot Unknown about 100 feet.

content.description: 200 feet downstream from the tomstone on your left is a gully with walls on both sides. Knot Unknown ascends an obvious crack up the right wall. Good rock and the steep section up high is easier than it looks. For an alternate start, try the left angling crack just a few feet to the right, still keeps it at same rating. Morning shade.
content.protection: Single .5, doubles .75 through#2, triples on #2 and #3, single #4 for the finish. Hexes are also nice to supplement.

content.description: First crack just right of the tombstone. Start on bouldery buldge, protect in horizontal if you wish. Next move on ledge is the pg13 part, the shorter you are the scarier it will be, stretching high to place a small cam on a balancy smear move. Continue through sugary section to better rock under and to right side of large roof and good hands to 3 bolt anchor
content.protection: Doubles through #4, except triples on #3, hexes also useful

climbs.name: Into the Maelstrom
climbs.fa: FA: Scott Duemler. FFA Christian Schrader, Tyler Mattix

content.description: The first pitch (10d, 90ft) starts tight fingers then to fingertips toward a fun move past a small roof, then more tight fingers and tips to awkward hands then easier ground to anchors. P2 (5.12-, 105ft) is crux, starts tight fingers and tips on series of stretchy moves to ledge, then slightly overhanging tight fingers with poor stemming, past 2 bolts, then hang left to clip 2 more bolts over steep dihedral with seam, crimps, and friction for feet (yikes) to anchor. Rating is approximate on pitch as first ascending party was not worthy to finish the pitch so if you get it, please update. P3(5.10d, 80ft) nice short corner with good fingers past pin to bulges with good rests and fun climbing. Finishes on short but strenuous OW bit after a bolt.
content.protection: Lots of thin stuff, I'd say 3 00's and 3 0's (I'm talking metolious sizes here) plus nuts (ball nuts are great), and otherwise doubles to #3 BD with a single #4 and single #5, plus a half dozes draws and a few extenders.
content.location: Accessed by rappel. Route is upstream, just around corner from bird of prey on large, obvious corner system but the wall starts in water. From parking area go down main trail about 100 feet and look for a faint trail (i left a cairn)angling right. Follow it on highest point between the two canyons, looking for cairns once you get on bare rock toward the cliff-end. Once you get to a small saddle you'll follow cairns to right, below high point, along ledges and down some until you reach the overlook above the main canyon/creek down below. Look for the rap anchors, close to tree on edge. Approach is somewhat wandering but easy going, 15minutes.3 raps with a 60m is fine. If you want the option to bail to the water (thigh deep)you'll need a 70m from the start of pitch 1 though.

content.description: P1:Past a couple of bolts to a thin, balancey section (10+) to angled ledge then into chimney, which isn't as hard as it looks, past one bolt. Then committ to difficult smearing with nice finger crack (5.11a/b) and perfect rock/pro to a juggy finish. P2: 50 feet of short overhangs and some offwidth (5.10-). Beautiful climbing on P1 crux.
content.protection: 3 bolts and standard rack plus doubles in .5 and .75
content.location: As you are walking through the middle section look to your right for a large (300ft) wall of very nice, angular rock just past a water crossing. BOP is the obvious crack splitting the large wall.

content.description: Walls to 200-300 feet right at the water edge.
